awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Optimized, Cost Effective LED Air Disinfection Reactor
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project addresses the need to improve the state of the art in efficient air disinfection by introducing a novel disinfection reactor developed around an optimized proprietary optical design in conjunction with an engineered suite of wavelengths delivered by Ultraviolet Light Emitting Diodes (UV LEDs). Despite the numerous benefits of LED based units, high UV LED costs currently restrict the commercial viability of UV LED based Air Disinfection units. Dot Metrics Technologies is proposing to develop a 10X to 20X cheaper disinfection unit by dramatically improving efficiency of the disinfection unit. This will be accomplished by creating an optimal optical design solution to air disinfection.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is project is immediate and long-term. Over 1.7 million healthcare associated infections (HAI) occur annually in the U.S. alone with an overall annual direct medical cost of HAI to U.S. hospitals ranging $28.4 to $33.8 billion. Drug resistance of pathogenic microorganisms that cause HAI is a growing problem. Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is emerging worldwide as a community acquired infection, and M. tuberculosis, which is known for its significant airborne transmission potential, has also become multi-drug resistant. As drug treatments grow increasingly inadequate against airborne pathogens, innovative, engineered UV disinfection systems such as the proposed solution may be one of the few remaining means to resolve the problem. In addition, increased use of mercury free UV technology will results in reduced hazardous environmental risks, and reduced costs associated with hazardous materials disposal.

The overall scope of the Phase I Program was to prove the feasibility of a transformative, chemical free, portable and low cost air disinfection system for recirculation using engineered polychromatic UV radiation provided by light emitting diodes (LEDs) to simultaneously target absorptive key elements within an airborne pathogen.  Dot Metrics Technologies achieved this goal, and enabled a viable 10X to 20X cheaper disinfection technology by pioneering a holistic approach that concurrently balanced various factors: optimization of optical and fluid-dynamic design for increasing the system efficiency, and the implementation and integration of the world’s first engineered multi-wavelength UV LED source, termed Poly UV™, resulting in more efficient DNA damage.

Dot Metrics Technologies successfully designed and implemented a fully functional prototype that pioneered, and experimentally demonstrated a groundbreaking effectiveness of Poly UV™, in conjunction with a proprietary optical reactor design that improved the system efficiency by more than 35X. The prototype was challenged with Bacillus subtilis, a non-pathogenic surrogate for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Bacillus subtilis is one of the most conservative vegetative microorganisms in bioaerosol studies, with UV resilience comparable to that of Bacillus anthracis spores (etiologic agent of anthrax). Experimental data obtained with the prototype challenged at constant flow rate compatible with the flow rate of human breathing, demonstrated a greater than 2.3 log reduction in Bacillus subtilis at low relative humidity, which translates into a nearly 6 log inactivation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

As a result of the Phase I Program, Dot Metrics also validated a method to efficiently target factors that directly affect the resistance to UV of microorganisms. In addiction to the significance of this scientific and technological breakthrough (the enhanced sensitivity to Poly UV™ has never been demonstrated before for airborne pathogens), these results are transformative. They substantiate that is possible to use a significantly reduced amount of UV optical power input, fewer UV LEDs, and hence achieve a significantly reduced cost disinfection system.

The intellectual merit centers on Dot Metrics Technologies’ proprietary optical design that compensates for the current low power output of UV LEDs. The solution implemented by Dot Metrics Technologies improved the state of the art in air disinfection by introducing innovation on a triple front. 1) It pioneered an engineered simultaneous multi-wavelength irradiation of pathogens to saturate their unique optical absorption centers, and exploit a mechanism comparable to the inner effect seen in fluorescence spectroscopy. 2) It introduced a method to target the factors that directly affect microorganism UV resistance. 3) It reduced the number of photons needed for DNA disruption by delivering them in an optically and fluid dynamically confined 3D flux, enabling unmatched energy efficiency.

The broader of impacts of this work encompass the potential to greatly decrease the exposure risk to healthcare associated infections (HAI). Over 1.7 million HAI occur annually in the U.S. alone with an overall annual direct medical cost of HAI to U.S. hospitals ranging $28.4 to $33.8 billion.
